block.comment: You do not need to modify or understand this script! This simply allows you to use the
These are simple wrappers to share to with the touch controls above.
This is simply a background. You don't need to do anything in this sprite.

Please see the spec for directions. All the red blocks are filled in. The grey blocks are for you to finish. You likely will not need to add any code to this sprite! The "Stage handles all the work of determining key presses and finger tags.

custom-block.comment: After reading the spec (twice!) start here.

block.comment: you will probably want to add better visual confrmation here!
This is a tester sprite! You should expand the test cases here, by adding items to the input and output lists, and attaching comments to blocks explaining your ideas.

scripts.comment: ============================================================================= EXAMPLES: These tester blocks take in a function -- something that you want to lest. The "inputs" are lists which have 1 item for each blank inputs the function will have. The outputs are the expected values after executing the function with that input. You can have multiple sets of inputs and outputs for a single block. (As many as you want!) This block will report a list of TRUE or FALSE values, corresponding to which tests pass. See these few simple examples. Note: you must leave the inputs to the block you are testing empty!\\\ SCROLL DOWN FOR YOUR GRADED TEST CASES! ================

custom-block.comment: Test that adding 1+1 = 2 The result is a 1 item list that is TRUE.
This adds a test which is supposed to report FALSE, because 2+4 is not 5.
This is an example of something you should actually test. Note that because the input to size of board is a list, we need to give our tester function a list of lists.

scripts.comment: ============================================== These are your graded test cases! For each of these functions you must have 2 different sets of input and expected output. Additionally, each function should have a brief comment explaining why your test cases are good / useful. You are more than welcome to add as many tests as you like, for additional blocks, as long as you meet the requirements above.

block-definition.comment: This is a game board which is expected to be square.
This creates a new empty board of n by n tiles
This is just like the ITEM OF block, but for our game board. You don't need to know how it works.
This is just like the REPLACE block, but for our game board. You don't need to know how it works.
This returns a new distinct copy of the input board which will help prevent you from accidentally reseting list items.
The block reports the score of an individual tile. For example: 2 -> 0 4 -> 4 8 -> 16 ... It uses the same formula given in the spec, just in a slightly different way.

This block takes in a function and two "sets" of items. The first are the INPUTS to the function. These must be a list whos length is equal to the number of inputs in the function. The OUTPUTS should be the same type as the output of the function. There must be the same number of inputs and outputs.

block.l: ERROR: The number of tests must be the same for inputs and outputs.

block.comment: This abstraction violation brought to you by Carlos ;)
